												First, go and download all the patches plus Thief 3 Gold, which combines the broken up levels. Yeah, Thief: Deadly Shadows suffered the same fate as Deus Ex: Invisible war... Broken up into many loads screens to the first Xbox.As for the game itself, it took me about 17ish (It says 19 on Steam, but 2 or so hours of it was a play thru months ago that only got to the second level, plus all the time it took to get the new patches running) hours to finish, and the levels, on average, lasted about 30~50minutes. This is a huge difference between both Thief Gold and Thief 2, which both took a solid 25 and 28 hours to finish; and on average, the levels lasted anywhere between 1 hour and 1 hour 45 minutes. The levels in Thief: Deadly Shadows are notoriously smaller.Gameplay wise, it's harder to do combat face on (Go figure), and everything else has been improved. Sure, it moves like♥♥♥♥♥due to the new engine, but the interface works a lot better than the first two Thiefs, plus I like seeing my own shadow and pressing up agaisnt walls. Unfortnuately, rope arrows have been removed and replaced with a weird wall climbing ability. Yeah, it's weird and slightly broken. Again, levels are smaller so... It doesn't feel like Thief. There's also a very broken faction system, and I'll just leave it at that.The only new edition is the hub which doesn't work because of how little there is to explore and why bother? Missions give so much loot... That you have to personally sell to vendors in the city. Sounds nice, at first, but gets very tedious when the guards and lack of hiding spots gets in the way. Now the kicker: Should you buy it? After you install the mods, it's only worth it if you want to see the story arch with Garrett end. Chances are, you've already played Thief Gold and Thief 2 in order, so it only makes sense to see how it ends with Garrett in Thief: Deadly Shadows.As for the 2014 Thief, ♥♥♥♥ that...

												What a real thief game should be. Much better than the first ones. The graphics are better and so are the levels. The levels are tighter, filled with more interesting things, and aren't hollow giant areas. This eliminates much of the wandering around with no clue.  The levels have better atmosphere, and the lighting is looks better too. There is also a better job with actually telling you what you need to do. There are still some problems. The knocking out is very spotty. Sometimes it won't knock out or kill someone if they are looking for you even if they haven't seen you and you are behind them. This makes no sense as the only way to draw them to the dark is make some noise so they come over. You can never tell if the attack will work. Sometimes if you are in front, or on the side, or 2/3 behind them it won't work and they will start attacking you. This makes no sense because of you surprise attack someone in the head in the dark, even if it isn't exactly behind them, it will do the same thing. Similarly you can shoot them in the head with an arrow and sometimes it will kill in one hit but if they are on the lookout it wont.........(?) Also you can never tell if you are close enough to hit them or not. The sound can be spotty too and you can't tell if they will be able to hear you or not. It is annoying how you have to go find the store to sell and buy things with how confusing the towns are and how your map tells you nothing. It would be better if you sold and bought stuff before each mission like in  the old days. All in all it is a better game, except still the supernatural creatures take some of the fun out of it. 8/10

To make matters short, at least at the front of this review, the only game I like out of the three is Thief II, though I only really enjoyed about 60% of that game and found the rest of it rather lackluster.As my other reviews say, the first Thief was good in virtually everything except for the level design, which killed it for me. The second game continued with all of the proper mechanics and had much better levels, at least for 60% of the game (as said above). This game, however, has much more issues with it than just the levels.Firstly, the game is terribly optimized with a horrible engine. From the start of the game, I had this weird stuttering issue where the camera would essentially shake as I looked around, bugging my eyes. Even with patches and such, the problem still occurred, though eventually it vanished for some weird reason. Regardless, that ended up just foreshadowing everything else I would have problems with in the game.The game even just crashed multiple times for me, for what reasons I could never tell. I never had either of the first two games crash or freeze (nor did System Shock 2).The levels themselves take a relatively long time to load. Now, I'm not an impatient person, and I understand if the level is initially loading up for the first time, but even just reloading a save I made 10 seconds ago will end up taking nearly 1 minute or more to load. The game first just goes to a black screen for about 20 seconds, then it will go to a loading screen, and finally get back to the level. But the weird thing is, about 50% of the time I would load a save or a new area would start up, the game would do a weird "freeze." The level would render but there would be no sound, and I couldn't move, attack, look around, jump, or do anything at all. What is odd is that the level would "start" in a halfway manner. For instance, at the beginning of the second mission, I could see subtitles of the guards talking outside, but the sound wouldn't play. Then about 20 seconds or more later, I could finally move and the sound would start, in the middle of their conversation. This happened in any place that I would load or enter.In terms of the controls, nothing is smooth. Just walking straight would have the game become choppy occasionally, but not because of a frame-rate drop. Getting near walls, even several inches away, would sometimes cause me to stop moving properly at the same speed. Leaning left and right is terribly slow and choppy. Jumping feels like you are disconnecting and reconnecting yourself via a chain to the ground. The third person isn't really anything well done. And of course, I ended up no-clipping through some walls in a few places and dying.Even attacking isn't proper. The very first guy I went up to in the second mission, I tried to use the blackjack on him. I was standing exactly behind him and never moved, and it took FIVE times for the blackjack to connect and knock him out. The first four times it just swung and nothing happened. I didn't bother moving, nor did I look at a different angle. I just stood exactly still and it missed four times, while neither of us moved.Further, just in the second mission, the game made me lose my controls multiple times as well. I don't know what made it occur, but twice when I was walking around, the game suddenly disabled my ability to creep, crouch, jump, or press against the walls. I could still walk and run, and I could still swing weapons or shoot arrows, but anything that required me to change my stature or get off the ground wouldn't work and I had to reload.In terms of looks, the graphics are somewhat better drawn, but they look more dull and less life-like. They don't render properly either, often flickering or disappearing throughout the level. The compass and visibility marker at the bottom is ugly; the menus are worse in design, and it is silly that things like options aren't available unless you quit the game. Big shining objects and doors are annoying.The game is missing some interesting items such as the Rope Arrow. The lockpicking is really nothing better than before. I thought it was better at first, because it was more interactive instead of just waiting, but in reality, you just twirl the mouse while clicking over and over. The only thing remotely better is the inventory as you can see the items as you swap through them, instead of trying to remember where a given item is in the list.Then you have the AI which is dumber than the first two games. I saw multiple guards walking into walls repeatedly. One even got onto a set of stairs, then went down 3 steps, back up, then back down, over and over in circles. Even more funny, in the City Hub, I knocked out random civilians and people just walked by them as if nothing was there.That's another thing... the City Hub. I thought it was going to be an interesting addition, but in fact, it isn't really. The areas I explored weren't that big, and there's only like 5 doors you can go into at a given time anyway. Essentially, it seems it only exists to add more roadblocks between you and your next mission, including having to repeatedly return to sell loot and buy new items (though I understand that more so). But really, it is a boring stopping point between missions.Now, despite my complaints with the first two Thief games, as I said, I thought Thief II was the best (which seems the general consensus) and I really enjoy the story and world atmosphere. However, I think the interior of the games actually ruin those things, for the most part. I didn't even get far enough into this game to see where the story was going, because of all of the above issues; but I finished both of the first two Thief games, even though I nearly hated the first one because of its levels.This game was easily the worst of the three overall, and I just can't put myself through anymore of it. Next, I will try my luck with the Thief reboot, though I already hear many people hate it. Here is hoping there are some better things done with it in comparison to Deadly Shadows.

Only a minute in, and the annoyingly slow run-speed of my character had already begun to irritate me. The graphics were a minor annoyance, as to be expected in a game this old, but the enviroments themselves seemed bland and lifeless. Upon reaching a ladder, my character proceeds to dry hump it repeatedly instead of actually climbing it. Eventually, I managed to overcome the incredible obstacle, and was able to continue onwards. Until, the game simply shut off. I didn't know what had happened. Had the game crashed? I tried booting it up again, but steam claimed it was already running. After about a minute, a new window of the game opened. Now, I've played a lot of older games. In fact, over 75% of the games I own come from the 90's. But never before had I seen a game that loaded by shutting down and then starting a new window. Being of a mind to go into game design myself, I was baffled as to why anyone would ever use THAT as a method of level loading. But even then, I was not deterred. Obviously, the rave reviews I had heard for this game had to have some basis. I continued on through the tutorial, which I was beginning to become quite sick of. For a game that had been flaunted as allowing you multiple ways through a scenario, this game had only allowed me an extremely linear set of options so far. After thirty minutes of slow-walking, I made it through the tutorial. Finally, I was free to play the game! I loaded the next level and decided to see if I could possibly take a more lethal approach. I attempted to snuck up behind a guard and stabbed him... Which is apparently not an instant kill. Having alerted every guard within an 100 mile radius, I decided to simply let them kill me so I could restart the level. After all, I had to assume the game had saved my progress automatically since I was offered no option to do so myself. I assumed wrong. There didn't seem to be a saving system of any kind, and I was sent back to the beginning of the tutorial. Unwilling to waste another 30 minutes of my life, I uninstalled the game and was thankfully able to get a refund from steam.So, to anyone reading this, don't waste your money on this game. Ignore all the rave reviews claiming it to stand the test of time. It does not.

												This review will be amended as I play through the game. If you strongly disagree with any material in the review, please leave a comment on my profile and we can discuss it further.The first thing you notice about Thief: Deadly Shadows are the load screens. These are understandable, given the higher level of graphical detail in this installment and being a home console release, but they are a bit disorienting compared to the much quicker load times of the previous installments. What's more noticeable are the various gameplay and story text blurbs included on these screens. For a series which previously established a noticeable lack of handholding the player, being reminded that you can knock enemies out with the blackjack is insulting.But once you arrive at the title screen the problems really begin to pile up. There's no option to view the intro this time around, instead forcing players to idle at the title screen for a short time before the intro starts (more on it later). The carefully designed pre-rendered mechanical background has also been abandoned for a 3D Thief logo rotating Deus Ex-style against a 2D background. The background depicting the City lit up at night during a thunderstorm is also questionable. If I had to guess I'd say that the setting or story of Thief: Deadly Shadows is more nature-oriented, maybe revisiting the Pagans or some impending conflict judging by the storm.The intro is noticeably lazier this time around, recycling a large amount of story art from the previous two games, as well as failing to provide any art that's relevant to the story in Deadly Shadows. The motion capture used during the action scene looks noticeably worse than what was seen in previous games, and the cheesy loot-collection jingle used during a cinematic made me roll my eyes.In the options screen the ways in which Thief: Deadly Shadows restricts freedom for the players rears its head. There's no rope arrow, and the default binds for the various arrow types are different than the defaults for the previous two games. Forward leaning, an important part of collecting loot, is removed entirely, and the option to move forward slowly is gone as well. A button to toggle between a first and third person view exists as well, just so you know how much this game panders to a console audience.The briefing screen has undergone a number of changes from it's previous iteration. Players can now perfom tasks while listening to the brief at the same time. This isn't really much of an improvement, since in the previous games briefings could simply be skipped with a button press. The briefings run for longer than in previous games and without the snappy editing and accompanying art they can be quiet boring to listen to on their own. There's no equipment to buy, and players are already told the explicit limit of what they can carry rather than just a large black box to group things in. An extra difficulty option has been added, and players can manipulate various difficulty factors such as AI behaviors.From the first moments of gameplay is when Thief: Deadly Shadows makes some of its strongest impressions on the player. Since it's a sequel running on a new engine the first moments of the game will have to work hard to offset whatever difficulties people have to adjusting to the new engine. Deadly Shadows manages to accomplish this poorly, by asking the player to walk, showing motion that feels extremely restrictive. You can even switch to 3rd person to see how ridiculous Garret's walking animation is.The tutorial level is a joke, plain and simple. The amount of handholding and bottlenecking the game does to introduce things to the player is a complete departure from how the series has operated before. Placing the player into situations devoid of tension do little to actually teach them about real gameplay.Also no freeview while climbing ladders. lol at the nonexistent range on the blackjack and the bow taking up most of the view.game has crashed multiple times within my first time playing, uninstalliing, dogshit game.

												A clumsy game. Movement physics akin to wading through mud, a recurrent jumping bug and obnoxious level transitions destroy any momentum this game could have had. Ion Storm couldn't get right something that Looking Glass Studios mastered four years before them. Curiously, after the technical disaster of Deus Ex: Invisible War, Ion Storm did not think not to use the same engine, warts and all, for Thief: Deadly Shadows. There is a third person mode and a first person mode. In an attempt to create two cameras, neither is particularly well implemented. The first person camera is tied to Garrett's model, and his animations are awkward and twitchy, which could easily induce motion sickness in some players. You will return to the City hub repeatedly after each mission. Each time, you will have to sneak through the same areas, around the same City Watch guards, patrolling the same paths. Ion Storm somehow did not realize this would instantly become incredibly tedious. Movement while crouching is absurdly slow, meaning to get around you will want to stand up and run. I cannot express in words how unbelievably braindead this idea is. Furthermore, it is now impossible to keep pace with a guard while crouching, so in order to pick his pocket you will need to stand up and run. Blackjacking is strangely convoluted: when you are behind someone, standing, the guard isn't searching, Garrett is raising his hand and the blue moon aligns, you might trigger a scripted knockout sequence. Otherwise you'll just have given the guard a friendly tap over the head that alerted him to your presence. Guards will notice when you put out lights, discouraging you from ever using water arrows. Garrett makes no sound at all when creeping or crouched, so there is almost never any reason to use moss arrows. As a result of this, you will most likely never spend any of the gold you can now accumulate over the course of the game. I finished the game with some 25,000 unspent gold and a full inventory of items I never used. At least in Thief 1 and Thief 2 I would spend all my gold on items I wouldn't use since there were no item caps and gold did not carry over between levels. A braindead lockpicking minigame that you will repeat over and over and over again. It locks you in place, so you cannot quickly check your surroundings without awkwardly fumbling out of the lockpicking minigame. Loot now sparkles, so you do not have to look around to find it. The climbing gloves are a poor man's substitute to rope arrows. Often you will try to climb a stone surface only to find that it is blocked off by an overhang, if you can even climb the surface at all—it seems as though the rules for which surfaces you can climb are not very consistent. Garrett has apparently forgotten how to swim, and simply drowns instantly upon making contact with water. Why in the ever living ♥♥♥♥ would the loading zones prompt you whether you want to move to the next area with a yes/no choice? I moved into the loading zone, I obviously want to load the next area. Do not ask me twice, you are not a Windows GUI.Expect problems even with the Sneaky Upgrade, as the Thief: Deadly Shadows engine is poorly optimized. I cannot in good faith recommend this game to anyone.

												Not a bad game, but has aged terribly and there are far more rewarding alternatives out there.This game has a lot in common with Deus Ex: Invisible War, which was made by the same developers and is based on the same engine. It's really not suited to open-ended environments and it shows in this game. About half your computer's power is spent trying to draw shadows and as a result, the levels themselves are too small and 'boxed in' to give this game the free-roaming sandbox feel that it's trying to achieve.I can't fault the atmosphere in this game. It's very dark and eerie, right down to Garrett's growling voice and background ambience when reading books. There are subtle prods towards cults and witchcraft and you find yourself in some very unfriendly places as the game progresses. It comes to a climax with 'the Cradle', the penultimate level of this game which is deemed to be one of the spookiest levels in a game, ever.However, the core gameplay is flawed. Moving about the world is a clunky experience. I like how you can look down and see your body, and that you can pull yourself up onto things, but I still felt disjointed and distant from the world. It just doesn't feel quite right. This extends to the combat, lockpicking and every bit of this game.There are occasional flashes of brilliance, like when I discovered another thief who I found breaking into the place I was sneaking about in. Running away from guards / black figures (COUGH Cradle) is a nerve-wracking experience and discovering hidden treasure makes me happier than I should be.This game is a very odd relic, stuck in an awkward transition period between old and new-style games. At the time, you could consider it a quirk of the game or assume that you were doing something wrong. Sadly, it just isn't worth playing today. Play Dishonored instead while you're waiting for Thief 4 to be released.

												An excellent staple of the Stealth Genre, Thief: Deadly Shadows is a game wherein you play Garett, an experienced thief who makes his fortune off of the work of others. The game has robust and intriguing characters, a reactive environment and surprisingly realistic stealth, and an overall enjoyable thrill of thievery and sneaking around.There are some things, however, that make this game awful. First is mostly a technical issue of screen problems and spontaneous lag, although this can be fixed with patches or some tweaking of the files. Not a dealbreaker.The combat's sluggish and unappealing; it doesn't flow well at all. Which, to be fair, it's not supposed to (stealth game, and all, that dagger's a last resort), but even when forced into combat, Garett really can't do much.And then there's the issue of your game completely wiping your save files when you try to save. No warning or reason, it will crash on the save screen and wipe your current saves. That being said, you can download save files from the internet and continue as you wish, but honestly, doing a lot of hard, sneaking work, going through the first few chapters and getting the game down, and then it wipes your saves?Do not buy this game. It's one of the few fun games in existence, yes, but with the technical issues stated above, it's clearly not worth the buy. Unfortunate.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												As far as I'm concerned, Deadly Shadows is to the Thief series what Invisible War is to Deus Ex, and I don't mean that in a bad way, because I enjoyed both. I mean this in terms of, it's using the same engine with similar system requirements, and suffers from similar problems.Let's start with what was added. The visuals are great, and even if they lack color, the pristine detail of nearly every model makes it look a generation ahead of its time. A lockpicking mechanic introduces gameplay more complex than "hold F to unlock". The city now serves as a hub, allowing the player to sell loot and buy equipment, and explore for extra challenges in an open-world environment. Even backtracking doesn't seem very tedious, due to the presence of hostile who roam the streets. A faction system allows the player to make friends or enemies with the Hammerites and Pagans, who in turn can provide backup in combat and freedom to explore their respective domains.However, a few things were removed. Rope and vine arrows are gone, replaced with gloves that allow Garrett to climb some walls. Also not present is the ability to swim. While Deus Ex: Invisible War dealt with this by simply removing water, Deadly Shadows has the player die in it, which just makes it seem like a tease. Moving the equipment purchases to shops means that, to restock, a player can no longer buy just before a mission. It goes hand-in-hand with the depth of city exploration, sure, but it makes a significant chunk of gameplay time just restocking. On a side note, the prices of these goods is far lower than that of the previous titles, so I don't find myself running into the same problem I had with Thief 2 (running out of useful items) as often here.The biggest problem with the game, though, is the inefficient and somewhat clunky (modified) Unreal Engine 2, which, as I stated earlier, was also used in Invisible War. The small areas are handled considerably better here than they are in IW. Enemy patrols and depth of level design are well done, but the level transitions between these smaller levels is a sword that cuts both ways. On one hand, it provides a quick, if unfair escape from pursuit. On the other hand, enemies are left in the exact same spot and alert level when doing so, and going back to the area will lead to a pummelling.Handling also feels a little awkward. The hit detection isn't all that great, and I frequently found myself falling from places against my will because the ledge detection is so awful. My most common problem was with the jumping glitch, where Garrett will appear to be floating just above the ground, with no ability to jump or crouch.Overall, it's a good Thief game, a good stealth game, and a good game in general. Apart from the occasional crash and the removal of some perfectly functional mechanics from the previous games, this one successfully experiments and improves on a few of the other gameplay aspects.

												An excellent stealth based game with some pretty good A.I.  This game is all about being a thief and staying hidden.  If you're looking for fast paced action, this game is not for you.  The main focus is on the story.Pros: The city is well crafted  with easy to recognize light and dark areas.  The clearly visible hiding spots are blended well into the environment making for some great atmosphere.  As you move around the world picking locks, extinguishing fires, and stealing valuables, the guards will notice anything out of place.  You really will feel that your actions have meaning in the world.  The stealth mechanics are almost unmatched.  But the best thing about this game is the story.  With excellent voice acting and plenty of cut scenes you will be immersed in the world.Cons: Although the city is completely accessible, the game is a little linear.  As with most games the mechanics aren't perfect and you may find some funny quirks.  Nothing game breaking though.Overall, a pretty amazing game for the time.  The stealth and guard A.I. are phenomenal, not to mention a great story to boot. Score: 8.8/10

The game does suffer from somewhat irritating bugs but most of these aren't game breaking. The game lacks the vast maps of the previous games but makes up for it somewhat in the variety of the missions and the relatively large quantity of them. This installation in the franchise boasts an explorable City environment where most people are not immediately hostile. The game is included with the previous two in a relatively cheap bundle and as such is a bargain. There is a new game coming out soon that is to be a reboot of the series and is available for pre-order at this time.

												This is one of the best games I have ever played. Perhaps I hold it to such a high standard because it may be saturated in nostalgia, as I have played it at a young age. This is the third game in the Thief series, and if you can't stand the older graphics of the first two games, I would recommend picking this one up, although even these graphics are relatively dated, so keep that in mind. Thief has a level of atmosphere that I haven't really seen any games match in comparison. The soundtrack is absolutely amazing, and creepy at times. There is a horror mission that might make the game worth picking up alone. As far as story goes, you may have guessed it, your'e a Thief. Your'e character is Garrett, a cynical, and sarcastic loner, that just wants to be left alone to ply his trade. As you start out you're just doing thievish things, but then the story takes a mystical turn, as an old guild of sorts requires your'e help. The story has some underlying themes as well, that I think are noteworthy. I would recommend downloading the fan made patch if you have windows 10, as this may cause slight glitches. I give this game a 10/10. In part because of nostalgia, and I think it would truly deserve this rating at the time it came out.
